dt: In figurative use, a {phrase}bad apple{/phrase} or {phrase}rotten apple{/phrase} is a bad member of a group who causes problems for the rest of the group.

dt.t: A few {it}bad apples{/it} cheated on the test, and now everyone has to take the test again.
One {it}rotten apple{/it} ruined the day for the rest of us.

dt: {bc}a person or thing that someone loves very much

dt.t: His daughter is {it}the apple of his eye{/it}.

shortdef: a round fruit with red, yellow, or green skin and firm white flesh —often used before another noun

I look {it}bad{/it} in this hat. = This hat looks {it}bad{/it} on me.
That hat doesn't look {it}bad{/it} on you. [=that hat looks good on you]

dt: {bc}having, marked by, or relating to problems, troubles, etc.

dt.t: good and {it}bad{/it} news
They have remained together in good times and {it}bad{/it} (times).

a {it}bad{/it} omen
{it}bad{/it} luck/fortune
Things are looking pretty {it}bad{/it} for us at this point.
I have a {it}bad{/it} feeling about this.
I couldn't take a picture because the lighting was {it}bad{/it}.
It's a {it}bad{/it} day for a picnic.
She made a {it}bad{/it} marriage.
Is this a {it}bad{/it} moment/time to have a word with you?

dt: {bc}not producing or likely to produce a good result

dt.t: a {it}bad{/it} deal
a {it}bad{/it} risk
a {it}bad{/it} idea/plan
The plan has its good points and its {it}bad{/it} points.
a {phrase}bad debt{/phrase} [=a debt that will not be paid]
a {phrase}bad loan{/phrase} [=a loan that will not be repaid]
The movie got {it}bad{/it} reviews.

dt: {bc}not healthy {bc}marked or affected by injury or disease

dt.t: His health is pretty {it}bad{/it}. = He's in pretty {it}bad{/it} health.
The patient was pretty {it}bad{/it} [={it}ill, sick{/it}] last week and even {it}worse{/it} yesterday but is doing better now.
He came home early because he was feeling pretty {it}bad{/it}. [=he wasn't feeling well]

{it}bad{/it} teeth
a {it}bad{/it} diet
a {it}bad{/it} influence
{phrase}bad cholesterol{/phrase} [=a type of cholesterol that can cause serious health problems when there is too much of it in your blood]
Eating too much can be {it}bad for{/it} you. = It can be {it}bad for{/it} you to eat too much.
Eating all that candy is {it}bad for{/it} your teeth.
Watching too much TV is {it}bad for{/it} children.

dt: {bc}not morally good or right {bc}morally evil or wrong

{it}bad{/it} conduct/behavior
a man of {it}bad{/it} character
{it}bad{/it} intentions/deeds

a {it}bad{/it} dog

dt: {bc}not skillful {bc}not doing or able to do something well

dt.t: a {it}bad{/it} musician
a {it}bad{/it} doctor
She was pretty {it}bad{/it} in that movie. [=she did not act well]
a doctor who's {it}bad at{/it} treating nervous patients
He's very/really {it}bad at{/it} expressing his true feelings.

dt: {bc}having a tendency not to do something

dt.t: He's {it}bad about{/it} getting to work on time. [=he often fails to get to work on time]
I'm very {it}bad about{/it} remembering people's birthdays. [=I often forget people's birthdays]

dt: {bc}not happy or pleased {bc}feeling regret or guilt about something

dt.t: I {phrase}feel bad{/phrase} about what happened. [=I regret what happened]
She {it}felt bad{/it} that she forgot to call. = She {it}felt bad{/it} about forgetting to call.
She's in a {it}bad{/it} mood. [=an angry mood]
He has a {it}bad{/it} temper. [=he's bad-tempered; he becomes angry easily]
She's in {it}bad{/it} trouble.
He has a {it}bad{/it} cough/cold.
That bruise looks {it}bad{/it}: you'd better see a doctor about it.
How {it}bad{/it} is the pain?

dt: {bc}no longer good to eat or drink {bc}not fresh

dt.t: the smell of {it}bad{/it} fish
Is the milk still good or has it {phrase}gone bad{/phrase}? [={it}spoiled{/it}]
He's the {it}baddest{/it} guitar player you'll ever hear!
Don't mess around with him. He's a {it}bad{/it} dude.

utxt.t: There's more goodness than {it}badness{/it} in him.

dt: {bc}from a bad state or condition to an even worse state or condition

dt.t: The company has been struggling for years, and things have recently gone {it}from bad to worse{/it}.
Without enough funding, public services are {it}in a{/it} pretty {it}bad way{/it} right now.
The patient was {it}in a bad way{/it} last week but is doing better now.
All things considered, she's {it}not{/it} a {it}bad{/it} singer. [=she's a pretty good singer]
{ldquo}How are you?{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}Not{/it} (too/so) {it}bad{/it}, thanks. And you?{rdquo}

dt: used to show that you are sorry or feel bad about something

dt.t: It's {it}too bad{/it} [={it}unfortunate{/it}] that John and Mary are getting divorced. = It's {it}too bad{/it} about John and Mary getting divorced. [=I'm sorry to hear that John and Mary are getting divorced]
{ldquo}I won't be able to come to the party.{rdquo} {ldquo}(That's) {it}Too bad{/it}. I was hoping you'd be there.{rdquo}

dt: used in an ironic way to show that you are not sorry or do not feel bad about something

dt.t: {ldquo}But I need your help!{rdquo} {ldquo}(That's just) {it}Too bad{/it}.{rdquo}
